title: Python Basics: Variables, Functions, and Loops
description: A beginner-level course covering the three foundational building blocks of Python programming: variable assignment and data types, function definition and invocation, and loop constructs for iteration.
learning_goal: Understand and apply Python variables, functions, and loops to write simple programs.
expected_knowledge: Python's dynamic typing system and built-in data types
Function definition syntax including parameters and return values
Differences between for loops and while loops
expected_skills: Create and manipulate variables of different types
Write reusable functions with parameters and return values
Use for and while loops to iterate over data

modules.title: Variables and Data Types
modules.description: Learn how to store data in variables and work with Python's built-in types.
modules.learning_goal: Understand variable assignment, dynamic typing, and type conversion.
expected_knowledge: Built-in types: str, int, float, bool, None
Type checking with type() and conversion functions

concepts.title: Variable Assignment
concepts.definition: A variable is a name that refers to a value in memory, created using the = operator.

concepts.title: Dynamic Typing
concepts.definition: Python infers the type of a variable from the value assigned to it, without explicit type declarations.

exercises.description: Create variables of each built-in type (str, int, float, bool) and print their types using the type() function.
exercises.reference_solution:
name = "Alice"
age = 30
height = 1.75
is_student = True
for var in [name, age, height, is_student]:
    print(type(var))
exercises.grading_criteria: All four types correctly assigned and printed.

concepts.title: Built-in Data Types
concepts.definition: Python's core data types include str, int, float, bool, and NoneType.

concepts.title: Type Conversion
concepts.definition: Converting a value from one type to another using functions like int(), str(), and float().

exercises.description: Write a program that reads a number as a string, converts it to an integer, doubles it, and prints the result as a string.
exercises.grading_criteria: Correct use of int() and str() conversions with arithmetic.

modules.title: Functions
modules.description: Learn to define, call, and compose functions for reusable code.
modules.learning_goal: Define functions with parameters and return values to organize code.
expected_knowledge: def keyword and function definition syntax
Parameters, default values, and keyword arguments

concepts.title: Function Definition
concepts.definition: A function is defined using the def keyword, followed by a name, parameters in parentheses, and a colon.

concepts.title: Parameters and Default Values
concepts.definition: Functions accept parameters as inputs, which can have default values specified with = in the definition.
examples:
def power(base, exponent=2):
    return base ** exponent

exercises.description: Write a function greet(name, greeting='Hello') that returns a formatted greeting string. Test it with and without the default parameter.
exercises.reference_solution:
def greet(name, greeting="Hello"):
    return f"{greeting}, {name}!"

print(greet("Alice"))
print(greet("Bob", "Hi"))
exercises.grading_criteria: Function uses default parameter correctly; both calls produce expected output.

concepts.title: The return Statement
concepts.definition: The return statement sends a value back to the caller and terminates function execution. Without it, a function returns None.
examples:
def add(a, b):
    return a + b
return a // b, a % b  # multiple values

concepts.title: Practical Function Design
concepts.definition: Well-designed functions handle edge cases, have clear inputs and outputs, and can be composed together.

exercises.description: Write a function calculate_average(numbers) that returns the average of a list. Handle the empty list case by returning 0.
exercises.grading_criteria: Correct average calculation; returns 0 for empty list.

modules.title: Loops and Iteration
modules.description: Learn to repeat operations using for and while loops with flow control.
modules.learning_goal: Use loops to iterate over data and control execution flow.
expected_knowledge: for loop syntax with sequences and range()
while loop syntax with condition checking
expected_skills: Write for loops over lists and ranges
Write while loops with proper termination
Use break and continue for flow control

lessons.title: For Loops and the range() Function

concepts.title: For Loop
concepts.definition: A for loop iterates over each item in a sequence (list, string, range), executing the loop body for each item.

concepts.title: The range() Function
concepts.definition: range() generates a sequence of numbers for use in for loops, accepting start, stop, and step arguments.

exercises.description: Use a for loop with range() to print all even numbers from 0 to 20 (inclusive).
exercises.grading_criteria: Correct use of range with step; prints 0, 2, 4, ..., 20.

concepts.title: While Loop
concepts.definition: A while loop repeats its body as long as a boolean condition remains True.

concepts.title: Break and Continue
concepts.definition: break exits the loop immediately; continue skips the current iteration and proceeds to the next.

concepts.title: Nested Loops
concepts.definition: Loops placed inside other loops, where the inner loop runs completely for each iteration of the outer loop.

exercises.description: Write a function find_common_elements(list1, list2) that uses a loop to find and return elements present in both lists.
exercises.grading_criteria: Correctly uses loop and conditional; returns shared elements.
